newsitem.title: USA: CSCE coffee called to open little changed.
newsitem.headline: CSCE coffee called to open little changed.

text.p: CSCE coffee futures were called to open little changed Wednesday, but some traders expected the market to follow through on Tuesday's gains.
"Overall, I like the market," one floor trader said. "It's called unchanged, but I wouldn't be surprised to see it come in 2.00 (cents per lb) higher."

New York arabica futures settled mostly higher on Tuesday, bolstered by news roaster Folgers raised its retail ground coffee prices. July arabicas ended up 2.55 cents at 198.95 cents after ranging between 201.50 and 196.00 cents. Spot May surged 6.25 cents per lb on the day, to 226.50 cents, while the back months closed 2.00 higher to 3.00 lower.
The nearby May/July switch, a barometer of nearby availability, ballooned to 27.45 today from 23.85 at the close on Monday.
Technically, traders said July would face resistance at 203.50 cents, a life-of-contract high set on Friday. Support was seen at Tuesday's low of 196.00 cents.

After Tuesday's close, the CSCE reported certified coffee stocks fell 1,500 bags, to 47,103 bags as of April 28. There were 3,000 bags of coffee pending grading, the exchange said. widened to 23.85 today from 23.10 at the close on Friday.
Merrill Lynch said in its bi-weekly commodity report that coffee prices in New York were likely to stay firm until the September contract's expiry due to the lack of supplies.
LIFFE coffee futures erased early losses and traded a touch higher at midday Wednesday. At the break, July was up $4, to $1,602, while spot May rose $3, to $1,535.
